awd_titl_txt: Program Support Office for the Interagency Ocean Observation Committee
awd_abstract_narration:
The PI's request funding to provide partial support for the Interagency Ocean Observation Committee (IOOC) support office hosted at the Consortium for Ocean Leadership (COL). The IOOC Support Office will continue to provide project management and meeting support services for the IOOC.

Interagency collaboration is essential to achieve ocean science and technology priorities and, in particular, for planning and coordination of an ocean observation system. The IOOC support office provides administrative assistance to the federal agencies on all of the IOOS planning activities. An IOOC that is able to effectively support these goals will make meaningful contributions to broader societal goals related to climate, maritime operations, natural hazards, national security, public health, ecosystems, and natural resources.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Interagency Ocean Observation Committee (IOOC) is critical in advancing how we observe and understand the ocean. Between 2022 and 2024, the IOOC collaborated with U.S. federal agencies, researchers, and international partners to enhance systems that monitor ocean and coastal environments. These efforts address critical challenges such as climate variability, coastal resilience, ecosystem health, and maritime safety.

Key Outcomes and Achievements

  • The IOOC developed and adopted its inaugural Strategic Plan (2024–2029), a comprehensive roadmap for advancing U.S. ocean observing capabilities. This plan focuses on building an integrated, cutting-edge ocean observing system, fostering diverse partnerships, and ensuring long-term sustainability to meet national and global needs.

  • The Ocean Societal Indicators (OSI) Task Team collected and analyzed 11 suites of ocean societal indicators to identify trends and gaps in existing data. This effort resulted in creating an Ocean Societal Indicator database and a summary report with actionable recommendations for integrating socioeconomic and ecological indicators into ocean observing systems. These findings were shared with federal agencies to support science-based decision-making for ocean and coastal management.

  • The Biology-Integrating Core to Essential Variables (Bio-ICE) Task Team reconciled U.S. IOOS core biological variables with global standards such as GOOS Essential Ocean Variables (EOVs) and Essential Biodiversity Variables (EBVs). The team published two reports on marine mammals and corals, identifying spatial and temporal observation synergies and proposing standardized data collection and delivery pathways. The naming conventions and protocols developed by the team enhance the interoperability of biological observations across national and global systems.

  • The Underwater Glider User Group (UG2) expanded its membership to over 700 members, fostering collaboration among researchers, operators, and industry professionals. UG2 hosted workshops in Seattle (2022) and Ann Arbor (2024), bringing together global participants to share knowledge, refine best practices, and strengthen underwater glider networks. UG2 also launched a new website, facilitated webinars, and provided training opportunities to improve resource sharing and knowledge distribution.

  • The Coastal Climate Signal Task Team began planning a national implementation framework to detect and respond to coastal climate change. The team identified gaps in current observation systems based on recommendations from the Optimizing Ocean Observing Networks for Detecting the Coastal Climate Signal workshop. It proposed strategies to improve monitoring and adaptation efforts.

  • The IOOC supported U.N. Decade-endorsed programs such as Observing Air-Sea Interactions Strategy (OASIS) and MarineLife2030 (ML2030), which promote equitable collaboration and capacity-building worldwide. The committee also advanced the outcomes of OceanObs’19 by improving the integration of global ocean observing systems, enhancing interoperability, and aligning efforts with national and international priorities.

Broader Impacts

The IOOC’s work delivers tangible benefits to society by supporting improved weather and climate forecasts, enhanced maritime operations, ecosystem monitoring, and natural hazard preparedness. Integrating socioeconomic and ecological data into observing systems empowers decision-makers to address critical challenges such as coastal resilience and sustainable resource management.

Programs like UG2 and U.N. Decade initiatives foster international collaboration and equity, ensuring global participation in addressing shared ocean challenges. By advancing the U.S. Integrated Ocean Observing System (IOOS) and fostering partnerships, the IOOC strengthens the ability of science and technology to support societal needs and promotes a more sustainable and resilient future for ocean science.
